close_symbols: type/definition of worker_pool and its element type (daemon->worker_pool)
declaration/type of daemon->itc and functions: MHD_itc_activate_, MHD_itc_destroy_chk_, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_, MHD_ITC_IS_INVALID_
declaration/type of daemon->tid and functions/macros: MHD_thread_handle_ID_is_valid_handle_, MHD_thread_handle_ID_join_thread_, MHD_D_IS_USING_THREADS_
declaration/types/macros related to sockets: MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, MHD_socket type, shutdown prototype
definitions/macros for EPOLL_SUPPORT and functions/macros: MHD_D_IS_USING_EPOLL_, daemon->epoll_fd, daemon->epoll_upgrade_fd
prototypes of gnutls cleanup functions used: gnutls_dh_params_deinit, gnutls_priority_deinit, gnutls_certificate_free_credentials, gnutls_psk_free_server_credentials and types they take
declarations/types of daemon fields used that are pointer-like: connections_head, cleanup_head, suspended_connections_head, new_connections_head, urh_head
declarations/types of auth-related pointer fields: daemon->digest_auth_random_copy, daemon->nnc and any NN/C structure types
prototypes of memory and error helpers used: free, MHD_PANIC, mhd_assert, MHD_DLOG
definitions of macros controlling compilation in the function: MHD_USE_POSIX_THREADS, MHD_USE_W32_THREADS, HAVE_LISTEN_SHUTDOWN, EPOLL_SUPPORT, HTTPS_SUPPORT, UPGRADE_SUPPORT, DAUTH_SUPPORT
explanation: To decide whether pointers in MHD_stop_daemon should be const-qualified we must know the exact declarations and expected mutability of each pointer used or passed to functions. The complete struct MHD_Daemon is required to see every pointer field (worker_pool, itc, tid, connection list heads, auth buffers, TLS credential handles, etc.) and their declared types. The worker_pool element type and close_all_connections prototype are required because the code indexes, writes into, frees, and passes the pool elements (and the daemon itself) — that determines whether a pointer must be non-const. The itc-related types and functions (MHD_itc_activate_, MHD_itc_destroy_chk_, MHD_ITC_IS_VALID_/INVALID_) must be known to determine whether those APIs mutate the pointed object (thus precluding const). Thread-handle types and thread helper functions/macros determine whether tid is a pointer type or an opaque handle that must be mutable. Socket-related declarations (MHD_socket_close_chk_, MHD_INVALID_SOCKET, shutdown) and EPOLL-related fields show whether file-descriptor fields are simple integers or pointer-like and whether operations modify state. The gnutls cleanup function prototypes and the types of TLS credential members show whether those members are passed to functions that take non-const pointers (i.e. are modified/freed). The connection-list and auth-buffer field types (connections_head, cleanup_head, suspended_connections_head, new_connections_head, urh_head, digest_auth_random_copy, nnc) are needed to determine if they are mutated here or by callees, so whether they could be const. Standard helpers and diagnostics (free, MHD_PANIC, mhd_assert, MHD_DLOG) and the conditional-compilation macros are included so the analyzer can determine which branches are compiled in and whether called routines accept const pointers or modify the pointed objects. Together these symbols let a reviewer determine for each pointer usage whether const qualification would be appropriate (i.e. the object is not modified here or by any called function) or is forbidden because the object must be mutable.
